question: What does the 'lifetime access' offer in the Machine Learning Program?
reference_answer: Lifetime access in the Machine Learning Program means that you only pay once to join the program and get immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. This includes 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, the entire source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to your instructor, and a program certificate upon completion. The lifetime access removes any pressure from having to complete the program when life gets in the way.

question: What are some of the skills and techniques I will learn in this machine learning program?
reference_answer: In this program, you will design and write the code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch. You will learn best practices to tackle significant challenges that machine learning engineers face in real-world scenarios. Some of the techniques you will learn include active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, test-time augmentation, and testing.

question: What are some of the topics covered in the first and second sessions of the course?
reference_answer: The first session of the course covers topics like collection strategies, dealing with selection bias, labeling data, and active learning using uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies. question: What skills and techniques will I gain and learn from this machine learning program?
reference_answer: You'll design and write the code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices to tackle significant challenges in building, evaluating, running, monitoring, and maintaining machine learning systems in real-world scenarios. You'll also learn techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, test-time augmentation, and testing.
